contentrichtext.text: [[Image:soaries def.jpg|thumb|right|DeForest Soaries]] '''Reverend DeForest Blake "Buster" Soaries, Jr.''' (born August 20, 1951 in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York]]) is an [[African-American]] [[Baptist]] minister, author and public advocate, from [[Montclair, New Jersey]].<ref>Peterson, Iver. [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D01E3DF1130F937A15752C0A96F958260 "IN PERSON; He's at Home In the Pulpit, Wherever It Is"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 24, 1999. Accessed December 3, 2008.</ref> He is the former [[Secretary of State of New Jersey]] and former chairman of the federal [[Election Assistance Commission]]. Additionally, he is the senior pastor of First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens in [[Somerset, New Jersey]], a position he has held since November 1990. Soaries received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Fordham University]]; a [[Master of Divinity]] degree from [[Princeton Theological Seminary]]; and a [[Doctor of Ministry]] degree from [[United Theological Seminary]]. He has also received five honorary Doctorate degrees from other institutions. He is married to the former Margaret Donna Pleasant. The couple has twin sons, Malcolm and Martin. Soaries served as Secretary of State of New Jersey from January 1999 through January 2002 under then-Governor [[Christine Todd Whitman]]. In that position he endorsed further funding for the arts, and served as an unofficial general advisor to the governor. He also created [[V-FREE]], a statewide youth violence prevention program. In 2002, Soaries was an unsuccessful Republican candidate for the U.S. House of Representatives from the [[New Jersey's 12th congressional district|12th C.D. of New Jersey]], losing to incumbent Democrat [[Rush D. Holt, Jr.]]. A proponent of faith-based community development, and of President [[George W. Bush|Bush]]'s [[faith-based initiative]], Soaries, through church donations, formed several [[non-profit]] community development agencies, including the Renaissance Community Development Credit Union, [[Renaissance Education & Technology Academy]] and the Harvest of Hope Family Services Network. Soaries was chosen by [[Coretta Scott King]] as the keynote speaker at the 2000 [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] celebration in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]]. He has also worked for the [[Urban League]] and [[Operation PUSH]]. In 2005, Dr. Buster Soaries began a pilot program entitled dfree at the First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens. dfree is a strategy to help individuals, families and organizations get out of debt, overcome the culture of debt and attain financial independence. After four years of using the dfree strategy to motivate families to pay off debt and use resources that facilitate financial freedom.<ref>[http://thegrablegroup.com/resources/tips/dfree-helping-people-organizations-overcome-culture-debt/ "dfree"]</ref> In 2010, Dr. Buster Soaries was the subject of a CNN documentary investigation into the creative and proactive ways an African-American faith community is addressing the challenges of the national economic crisis.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/linkto/opk/almighty.debt/index.html "Almighty Debt | CNN"]</ref> Today Pastor DeForest “Buster” Soaries preaches a gospel of personal financial responsibility, and cultivating a value system of “faith in action” – expressed as optimism rooted in reality. He wants to help his parishioners – and Black America – achieve spiritual growth, educational excellence and economic empowerment.<ref>[http://thegrablegroup.com/speakers/dr-buster-soaries-popular-speaker-agent-change/ "Dr. Buster Soaries Bio | The Grable Group"]</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.eac.gov/soaries.asp?format=none Official Website] * [http://www.fbcsomerset.com First Baptist Church of Lincoln Gardens (Somerset, New Jersey)] * [http://www.mydfree.org/ Official dfree Website] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box|title=[[Secretary of State of New Jersey]]|before=[[Lonna Hooks]]|after=[[Regena Thomas]]|years=1998 – 2001}} {{s-end}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Soaries, Deforest | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American politician | DATE OF BIRTH = August 20, 1951 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Soaries, Deforest}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:African-American politicians]] [[Category:African-American writers]] [[Category:Secretaries of State of New Jersey]] [[Category:United Theological Seminary alumni]]
